description:
Plasmodium vinckei brucechwatti is a species of malaria parasite that infects mice and other rodents. It is a subspecies of the larger Plasmodium vinckei species, which is found in various rodent hosts in Africa.

Plasmodium vinckei brucechwatti is a single-celled eukaryotic organism that belongs to the phylum Apicomplexa. It has a complex life cycle that involves both a vertebrate host (the rodent) and an invertebrate host (a mosquito of the genus Anopheles). 

In the rodent host, the parasite undergoes a series of developmental stages, including the invasion of red blood cells, asexual reproduction, and the formation of gametocytes. The gametocytes are then taken up by a feeding Anopheles mosquito, where they undergo sexual reproduction and develop into sporozoites that can infect a new rodent host when the mosquito takes a blood meal.

Plasmodium vinckei brucechwatti is commonly used as a model organism in the study of malaria pathogenesis and the development of new antimalarial drugs and vaccines, as it shares many similarities with the Plasmodium species that infect humans.
